thread.title: Slow Internet? Check your connection, inside and out
thread.title_full: Slow Internet? Check your connection, inside and out | Dallas Morning News

author: Rossman
title: Slow Internet? Check your connection, inside and out
text:
A reader recently wrote complaining about slow Internet at her house.
She asked if I thought changing Internet providers would help and if there were any other choices besides the cable company and the phone company.
To begin troubleshooting a slow Internet connection, you should do some research to try to determine whether the slowness is coming from a poor connection to your provider or an issue with the network in your house.
First, I’d run an online speed test to see if the Internet connection to your house is as fast as you’re expecting. My favorite is at speedtest.net.
I suggest that you run the speed test on a computer that is connected to your home network with an Ethernet cable so you get a true test of the speed. It’s OK to run the speed test over Wi-Fi, of course, but I think you’ll get a truer result from Ethernet.
You should know the speed you’re paying for, and it should be close to what you see from the speed test.
If the numbers are way off, your first step should be to contact your Internet service provider and ask them why you’re seeing a difference.
If you’re paying for 24-megabit-per-second service and only seeing 2 mbps on the speed test, it’s probably a problem with your provider.
If you’re seeing decent speeds from the test but still experiencing slowness, especially over wireless, your Wi-Fi router might be to blame. Try accessing the Internet with different devices (computer, tablet, phone) to see whether surfing is slow for them all or just one device.
Power-cycling the modem or router is a good place to start your troubleshooting.
My Internet modem is also a wireless router, and I find I need to reboot it occasionally to speed things up when the going gets slow.
The easiest way to reboot is to unplug the box from its power supply, wait 30 seconds and plug it back in.
If there’s still a problem, look for causes of interference. Try moving the router to a higher place in the room or even a different room if you are able.
I used to keep my router inside my TV cabinet but found I get much better coverage if I set it on top of the cabinet behind my TV.
Of course, it’s better to set the router away from other electronics if you can. Also, microwave ovens and cordless phones can use the same radio spectrum (2.4 GHz) as your router, which might explain some intermittent slowness.
At my house, I purchased a separate Wi-Fi router to supplement the built-in router from my modem. My new router uses the 5 GHz radio band, which is faster and much less crowded.
I connected it to one of my modem’s Ethernet ports.
My house now has two Wi-Fi networks to use. One of them is usually working well.
The bottom line is that you need to do some testing on each part of the connection, both inside and out of your house. You should be able to zero in on the problem.
